to cradle all the weight of human care,

So let the rain fall soft, let time unwind,
and let the soul, at last, be left behind
the clamor of the week, the rush, the grind.

A chair, a cup, the hum of air—

while shadows stretch and time runs free.

and solitude becomes my friend.

*Alone I sit in this café,*
where strangers drink and laughter rings,
yet none may hear the thoughts I weigh,
nor trace the lines my heart still sings.

a taste of longing, sharp and deep.
I sip, I write, I feel complete—
the self a stage, the self a keep.

For in this hush, this quiet space,
the soul unfolds its hidden art.
No judge, no gaze, no need to chase
the ghost of what the world imparts.

The pen, a needle, stitches time,
each word a thread, each line a seam.
I sew the self, I stitch the rhyme,
and solitude becomes my dream.

So let them pass, let hours turn,
let silence wrap me like a shroud.
For here, in ink and coffee’s burn,
I find the self I’ve long been proud.
